name: Vanilla Fudge
description:
'''Vanilla Fudge''' is an American [[rock music|rock]] band from [[New York City]], formed in 1967 and originally active until 1970, during which time they released five [[album]]s. They became known for their [[hard rock]] [[arrangements]] of [[oldies|contemporary pop]] songs, particularly with their [[cover version|cover]] of "[[You Keep Me Hangin' On]]", a [[Motown]] song originally recorded by [[the Supremes]], which became a [[hit song|hit]] [[single (music)|single]] in 1968. After occasional reunions during the 1980s and early 1990s, the band reformed full time in 1999.

The group's foundational lineup remained consistent during 1967–1970, comprising [[vocalist]]/[[organist]] [[Mark Stein (musician)|Mark Stein]], [[electric bass|bassist]]/vocalist [[Tim Bogert]], [[guitarist]]/vocalist [[Vince Martell]], and [[drummer]]/vocalist [[Carmine Appice]]. Bogert retired from [[live music]] in 2009, whereafter [[Pete Bremy]] joined on bass; Bogert died from [[cancer]] in 2021. "The Fudge", as members call the group, is currently [[concert tour|touring]] with Stein, Martell, Appice, and Bremy, with [[concert]] dates scheduled through 2026.

Vanilla Fudge has been cited as "one of the few American links between [[psychedelia]] and what soon became [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]]" and as a [[Progressive rock#1966–1970: Origins|proto-prog]] band.
